item.title: sAPPα Peptide Promotes Damaged Microglia to Clear Alzheimer's Amyloid‐β via Restoring Mitochondrial Function
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: The function of microglia to clear amyloid β (Aβ) is critical for Alzheimer′s patients. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202400870), C. Qian and co‐workers show how the soluble amyloid precursor protein α (sAPPα) effectively enhances phagocytosis and metabolism of Aβ in damaged microglia by restoring mitochondrial function. sAPPα exhibits promising potential as a safe therapeutic agent or drug carrier for the treatment of Alzheimer′s disease. Cover created by Yingqi Tang.
item.content:encoded: The function of microglia to clear amyloid β (Aβ) is critical for Alzheimer′s patients. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202400870), C. Qian and co-workers show how the soluble amyloid precursor protein α (sAPPα) effectively enhances phagocytosis and metabolism of Aβ in damaged microglia by restoring mitochondrial function. sAPPα exhibits promising potential as a safe therapeutic agent or drug carrier for the treatment of Alzheimer′s disease. Cover created by Yingqi Tang.
item.dc:creator: Yingqi Tang, Yangang Wang, Ziran Gao, Jiayi Li, Lijia Zhang, Haoting Shi, Jingwen Dong, Shipeng Song, Chenggen Qian
item.dc:title: sAPPα Peptide Promotes Damaged Microglia to Clear Alzheimer's Amyloid‐β via Restoring Mitochondrial Function

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Backbone Modification in a Protein Hydrophobic Core
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Targeted backbone alteration is a powerful strategy for the design of protein mimetic macromolecules. The present work demonstrates artificial chain connectivity can be accommodated in the hydrophobic core of a complex tertiary fold with minimal impact on folded structure or folded stability.
Abstract Targeted protein backbone modification can recreate tertiary structures reminiscent of folds found in nature on artificial scaffolds with improved biostability. Incorporation of altered monomers in such entities is typically limited to sites distant from the hydrophobic core to avoid potential disruptions to folding. This is limiting, as it is advantageous in some applications to incorporate artificial connectivity at buried sites. Here, we report an examination of protein backbone modification targeted specifically to hydrophobic core positions and its impacts on tertiary folded structure and fold stability. Different artificial monomer types are placed at core, core‐flanking, or solvent‐exposed positions in a compact three‐helix protein. Effects on structure and folding energetics are assessed by NMR spectroscopy and biophysical methods. Results show that artificial residues can be well accommodated in the hydrophobic core of a defined tertiary fold, with effects on stability only modestly larger than identical changes at solvent‐exposed sites. Collectively, these results provide new insights into folding behavior of protein‐like artificial chains as well as strategies for the design of such molecules.
item.content:encoded:
Targeted backbone alteration is a powerful strategy for the design of protein mimetic macromolecules. The present work demonstrates artificial chain connectivity can be accommodated in the hydrophobic core of a complex tertiary fold with minimal impact on folded structure or folded stability.


Abstract

Targeted protein backbone modification can recreate tertiary structures reminiscent of folds found in nature on artificial scaffolds with improved biostability. Incorporation of altered monomers in such entities is typically limited to sites distant from the hydrophobic core to avoid potential disruptions to folding. This is limiting, as it is advantageous in some applications to incorporate artificial connectivity at buried sites. Here, we report an examination of protein backbone modification targeted specifically to hydrophobic core positions and its impacts on tertiary folded structure and fold stability. Different artificial monomer types are placed at core, core-flanking, or solvent-exposed positions in a compact three-helix protein. Effects on structure and folding energetics are assessed by NMR spectroscopy and biophysical methods. Results show that artificial residues can be well accommodated in the hydrophobic core of a defined tertiary fold, with effects on stability only modestly larger than identical changes at solvent-exposed sites. Collectively, these results provide new insights into folding behavior of protein-like artificial chains as well as strategies for the design of such molecules.
item.dc:creator: Yuhan Lin, W. Seth Horne
item.dc:title: Backbone Modification in a Protein Hydrophobic Core

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Unusual Stability of an End‐on Superoxido Copper(II) Complex under Ambient Conditions
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The unusual stability of an end‐on superoxido copper complex, [CuII(Me6tren)(O2⋅−)]+ (Me6tren=tris(2‐dimethyl‐aminoethyl)amine), observed in an oxygen‐enhanced atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP), was investigated. It was found that the corresponding peroxide complex and the complexes [CuI(Me6tren)(DMSO)]+ and [CuII(Me6tren)(OH)]+ participate in the overall reaction cycle.
Abstract Superoxido copper complexes play an important role as usually short‐lived intermediates in biology and chemistry. The unusual stability of an end‐on superoxido copper complex observed in an oxygen‐enhanced atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) led to a detailed mechanistic investigation of the formation of [CuII(Me6tren)(O2⋅−)]+ (Me6tren=tris(2‐dimethyl‐aminoethyl)amine) under ambient conditions. The persistence of the superoxido copper complex could be explained by a reaction cycle including the peroxido complex [(Me6tren)2CuII2(O2)]2+ together with [CuI(Me6tren)(DMSO)]+ and [CuII(Me6tren)(OH)]+ in the overall reaction.
item.content:encoded:
The unusual stability of an end-on superoxido copper complex, [CuII(Me6tren)(O2⋅−)]+ (Me6tren=tris(2-dimethyl-aminoethyl)amine), observed in an oxygen-enhanced atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP), was investigated. It was found that the corresponding peroxide complex and the complexes [CuI(Me6tren)(DMSO)]+ and [CuII(Me6tren)(OH)]+ participate in the overall reaction cycle.


Abstract

Superoxido copper complexes play an important role as usually short-lived intermediates in biology and chemistry. The unusual stability of an end-on superoxido copper complex observed in an oxygen-enhanced atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) led to a detailed mechanistic investigation of the formation of [CuII(Me6tren)(O2⋅−)]+ (Me6tren=tris(2-dimethyl-aminoethyl)amine) under ambient conditions. The persistence of the superoxido copper complex could be explained by a reaction cycle including the peroxido complex [(Me6tren)2CuII 2(O2)]2+ together with [CuI(Me6tren)(DMSO)]+ and [CuII(Me6tren)(OH)]+ in the overall reaction.
item.dc:creator: Chiara Eleonora Campi, Kostas Parkatzidis, Athina Anastasaki, Siegfried Schindler
item.dc:title: Unusual Stability of an End‐on Superoxido Copper(II) Complex under Ambient Conditions

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Molybdenum Sulfide Nanoflowers as Electrodes for Efficient and Scalable Lithium‐Ion Capacitors
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: The Cover Feature shows that molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) nanoflowers have enabled high‐energy, high‐power, and scalable lithium‐ion capacitor pouch cells for electric vehicle applications. The excellent performance was attributed to the fast surface redox reactions on the MoS2 electrode with tailored two‐dimensional nanostructure and nanoflower morphology that overcome the sluggish kinetics in conventional lithium‐ion capacitors. More information can be found in the Research Article by J. Liu and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202400907).
item.content:encoded: The Cover Feature shows that molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) nanoflowers have enabled high-energy, high-power, and scalable lithium-ion capacitor pouch cells for electric vehicle applications. The excellent performance was attributed to the fast surface redox reactions on the MoS2 electrode with tailored two-dimensional nanostructure and nanoflower morphology that overcome the sluggish kinetics in conventional lithium-ion capacitors. More information can be found in the Research Article by J. Liu and co-workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202400907).
item.dc:creator: Rameez Ahmad Mir, Amir Hosein Ahmadian Hoseini, Evan J. Hansen, Li Tao, Yue Zhang, Jian Liu
item.dc:title: Molybdenum Sulfide Nanoflowers as Electrodes for Efficient and Scalable Lithium‐Ion Capacitors

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Hydrogen Tunneling Exhibiting Unexpectedly Small Primary Kinetic Isotope Effects
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: A heavy pickup truck carries its load through a tunnel regardless of its molecular driver (H or D), thereby illustrating unexpectedly small primary H/D kinetic isotopic effects. These surprising results arise from the coupling of the tunneling H/D atoms with the N2 medium, thus highlighting a potential systematic oversight of quantum tunneling in many chemical reactions. More information can be found in the Research Article by C. M. Nunes and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202401323).

item.dc:title: Hydrogen Tunneling Exhibiting Unexpectedly Small Primary Kinetic Isotope Effects
